newsitem.title: USA: Venezuelan startup Santa Barbara mulls cargo.
newsitem.headline: Venezuelan startup Santa Barbara mulls cargo.

text.p: Venezuelan start-up Santa Barbara Airlines plans to add cargo capabilities to its business mix, its chief executive told Reuters this week.

"We will eventually get a dedicated cargo aircraft -- maybe shared with others -- sometime after the end of our first twelve months of operation," Frans Kramer, general manager and chief executive of the 23 day-old Maracaibo airline, said. Santa Barbara is one of the many new airlines in Latin America flying small jets within the region.
As the region opens its skies to others within the area, analysts are predicting big growth for these tiny regionals.

"Within the entire region, there is a potential for developing long, skinny routes which have no air service at present and which can profitably support daily service with the small jets," Robert Booth, a consultant with Aviation Management Services, wrote in a recent position paper.

Kramer feels the smaller markets are also ripe for cargo service. "We have already had requests to fly machinery and whatever else," he said, "but with our 48-seat aircraft our cargo capability is limited."
"Some routes may be more active in cargo than passenger," he said.
Santa Barbara will first do courrier service, he said.
The airline has one jet and will take delivery on another next month, Kramer said.
"Right now, our business plan is, we need to focus on transporting passengers," he said.
